lens.lens_summary: Visual principles for review micro-interactions that feel lightweight and inviting, derived from Tapper's pricing clarity needs and the Microinteractions book's 'Less Is More' feedback principles.

elements.title: Review Card Visual Weight Hierarchy
elements.problem: Traditional review forms feel like bureaucratic homeworkâ€”long, multi-field forms that signal 'this will take effort.' For stay-by-stay reviews (12+ reviews per lease), visual weight signals effort level. A heavy, form-like card creates review fatigue. Guests see the visual complexity and abandon before even starting. The microinteractions principle 'Less Is More' applies: feedback should match importance without overwhelming.
elements.solution: Design review prompts as lightweight cards with minimal visual weight: small footprint (max 360px wide on mobile), soft rounded corners (--rounded-xl: 12px), single-column layout, generous white space (--spacing-2xl: 24px internal padding). Use the purple palette's lightest tints for backgrounds (--bg-off-white: rgb(252, 250, 255)) to keep visual weight low. Limit visible fields to 2-3 items max: star rating (largest), optional comment field (secondary), optional issue flag (tertiary, small). Visual hierarchy through size, not color intensityâ€”keep the card feeling open and breathable, not dense. The card should feel like a quick interaction, not a form.

evidence.quote: Limit stay-by-stay reviews to 2-3 data points maximum: (1) REQUIRED: Overall rating (1-5 stars, single tap). (2) OPTIONAL: One-line comment (50 char max, encourages brevity). (3) OPTIONAL: Issue flag (binary yes/no: 'Was there a problem this stay?').
evidence.insight: Information architecture defines WHAT to show. Visual design defines HOW HEAVY it feels. 2-3 fields can still feel overwhelming if presented in a dense, form-like layout. Use visual weight (card size, spacing, color lightness) to make the minimal field count feel even lighter.

evidence.quote: Feedback: 'Less Is More'â€”match feedback to importance, don't overwhelm.
evidence.insight: Visual design IS feedback. A heavy, complex-looking card signals 'this is important and requires effort.' A light, simple card signals 'this is quick and easy.' The visual weight of the review card is feedback about how long the interaction will take.

evidence.quote: when it says something like, you know, I'm looking currently at the apartment I inquired about, it says four week rent, 2090 $2, if you select full time. Um, what does that include? Does that include the fees for booking?
evidence.insight: Tapper struggled with visual information density and ambiguity. Too many numbers, unclear hierarchy. The same applies to review cardsâ€”if they look dense and complicated, guests won't engage. Visual simplicity = cognitive simplicity.

evidence.quote: --spacing-2xl: 24px for section margins, --spacing-lg: 16px for section padding, --rounded-xl: 12px for prominent cards
evidence.insight: Use the design system's generous spacing tokens to create breathing room. 24px internal padding makes the card feel spacious, not cramped. 12px border radius softens visual weight compared to sharp corners.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text (4.5:1 minimum). Star rating icons at 24px minimum for touch targets.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Eye sees card as a whole first (light background, soft shadow), then star rating (largest element, centered), then optional comment field (secondary), then issue flag (smallest, bottom).
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'Warm, not cold. Soft backgrounds, not stark white.' Use --bg-off-white to create warmth. 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' Keep the card elegant but approachable through generous spacing and soft colors.

elements.title: Star Rating Visual Delight (Emoji Scale Alternative)
elements.problem: Traditional 5-star rating systems are functional but boring and bureaucratic. Stars feel like hotel review formsâ€”impersonal, transactional. For 12+ reviews per lease, the star rating becomes repetitive visual noise. The Microinteractions book emphasizes 'Feedback as a Personality-Delivery Mechanism'â€”the visual design should feel delightful, not administrative. Stars don't convey Split Lease's warm, human brand personality.
elements.solution: Consider two visual approaches: (1) **Stylized stars with micro-animations**: Large tap targets (40px minimum), custom-designed stars with rounded edges (not sharp points), brand purple fill (--primary-purple: #31135D) on tap with spring animation (--easing-spring from taste model). Each star subtly scales up on hover/tap for tactile feedback. (2) **Emoji mood scale (alternative)**: Replace stars with 5 emoji faces ranging from ðŸ˜ž (1) to ðŸ˜Š (5), sized at 40px each. Tapping an emoji triggers a gentle bounce animation. Use grayscale for unselected states, full color for selected. This approach feels more human and conversational, aligned with the taste model's 'human language' principle. Both approaches use consistent spacing (--spacing-md: 12px between rating elements) and ensure WCAG AA contrast.

evidence.quote: Feedback as a Personality-Delivery Mechanism: Feedback defines how the product feels.
evidence.insight: The star rating visual design IS the product's personality in this moment. Stars = corporate/hotel vibes. Emoji = human/warm vibes. Visual choice shapes emotional response. For a platform that values trust and community, consider emoji to feel less transactional.

evidence.quote: Warm, not cold. Trustworthy, not corporate. Rounded corners, human language, real data.
evidence.insight: Traditional stars are cold and corporate. Emoji scale or highly stylized, rounded stars align better with the warm, human brand personality. Rounded corners on stars = brand consistency.

evidence.quote: Make review submission a natural extension of the cleaning photo submission flow. The guest is already looking at evidence of the stay's condition; asking for their review in that moment is contextually perfect.
evidence.insight: If the review appears right after cleaning photos (a visual, image-based interaction), the rating mechanism should also feel visual and immediate. Emoji or large, tappable stars feel more aligned with the visual context than small, precise star ratings.

evidence.source: Style-guide.md, animation philosophy from taste model
evidence.quote: Fast response, gentle settle. User actions feel instant (< 100ms acknowledgment) but transitions are smooth (300-500ms). Spring easing for interactive elements.
evidence.insight: Tapping a star or emoji should feel instant (< 100ms visual feedback) with a gentle spring animation (300ms settle). This creates delight and confirms the action without feeling sluggish.

typography: If using emoji: 40px font size, system emoji font
If using custom stars: SVG icons, 40px size

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for unselected state (3:1 minimum against background). Selected state should be highly visible (7:1+ recommended). 40px minimum touch target per WCAG.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Rating mechanism is the PRIMARY visual element in the review card. Centered horizontally, largest interactive element on the card. Eye goes here first. Use size and centering to establish dominance.
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'One signature animation per componentâ€”restraint over spectacle.' The spring animation on tap is the signature moment. Also aligns with 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' Custom stars or emoji feel crafted, not generic.

elements.title: Review Streak Visual Progress Indicator
elements.problem: Guests completing 12+ reviews over a 3-month lease have no visual sense of progress or contribution. Each review feels isolated, not part of a pattern. The Microinteractions book's 'Loops' concept emphasizes showing long-term engagement patterns. Without visible progress, guests don't feel motivated to continue reviewing after stay 3-4. The review history dashboard (communicates-006) solves this, but the review PROMPT itself should also show progress to motivate completion in the moment.
elements.solution: Add a small, unobtrusive progress indicator at the top of the review card: 'Stay 3 of 12' or '25% reviewed' with a minimal progress bar (2px height, --primary-purple fill, --border-subtle background, 80px width). Use --text-xs: 11px for the text label, --text-light-gray color to keep it secondary. The progress bar uses a gentle fill animation (300ms, --easing-ease-out) when the card appears. This creates a sense of accomplishment ('I've done 3 already!') and shows the end is in sight ('Only 9 more'). Position at top-right of card to avoid interfering with primary action (star rating). For the final review (stay 12), show celebration: 'ðŸŽ‰ Final review!' with --accent-gold highlight to create closure.

evidence.quote: Loops: What happens when the microinteraction is used over time? Long loops change the interaction based on repeated use.
evidence.insight: A review streak indicator IS a long loop visualâ€”it shows the pattern of repeated use over time. By stay 8, seeing '8 of 12' creates momentum to finish. This is visual feedback about the loop itself.

evidence.quote: Create a guest-facing 'Your Reviews' dashboard showing their complete review history. Include summary stats at top: 'You've written 8 reviews â€¢ 85 guests found them helpful â€¢ You're in the top 20% of reviewers.'
evidence.insight: The dashboard provides comprehensive progress feedback. The review card prompt should provide MINIMAL progress feedbackâ€”just enough to motivate completion without overwhelming. A small '3 of 12' indicator is sufficient.

evidence.quote: On a 3-month lease with 4 nights/week, a single guest-host pairing generates ~12 separate stays. If every review requires the same effort, guests will experience review fatigue by stay 3-4 and stop participating.
evidence.insight: Visual progress indicators combat fatigue by showing 'you're making progress' and 'there's an end in sight.' Without this, guests feel like reviews are infinite and give up.

evidence.quote: --text-xs: 11px for smallest text, labels, badges
evidence.insight: Use the smallest text size (11px) for the progress indicator to keep it unobtrusive. It's important information but shouldn't dominate the card visually.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for progress text (11px requires 4.5:1 minimum). Progress bar visual contrast should be 3:1 minimum.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Progress indicator is TERTIARY. It's at the top-right but small and subtle. Eye sees card â†’ star rating â†’ comment field â†’ progress indicator. It's discoverable but not dominant. Creates ambient awareness of progress without demanding attention.
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'Relentless Personalization: The UI should adapt to who you are and where you are in your journey.' The progress indicator personalizes the review card based on the guest's position in the lease lifecycle. Also aligns with 'restraint over spectacle'â€”the indicator is minimal, not a large, colorful gamification element.

elements.title: Cleaning Photo â†’ Review Transition Visual Continuity
elements.problem: Layer 1 (works-001) establishes that review prompts should appear immediately after cleaning photo submission. But if the transition from photo view to review prompt is jarring (new screen, different visual context, hard cut), it breaks the flow and creates friction. The user's mental context is 'I just looked at cleaning photos' and suddenly they're in a different visual environment asking for a review. Context switching creates cognitive load and increases abandonment.
elements.solution: Design the review card to appear IN THE SAME VISUAL CONTEXT as the cleaning photo viewâ€”either as a slide-up overlay (from bottom of screen, 300ms animation, --easing-ease-out) or as an inline expansion below the cleaning photos. The review card should visually reference the cleaning photo: show a small thumbnail (60px x 60px, --rounded-md: 6px) of the cleaning photo at the top-left of the review card with text: 'How was your stay?' This creates visual continuityâ€”the guest sees the photo they just submitted, reinforcing context. Use the same background color (--bg-off-white) as the photo viewing screen to avoid jarring color shifts. The transition should feel like a natural next step, not a mode switch.

evidence.quote: Having quickly graspable bits of information made the transaction much faster than trying to save screens. Embed reviews in the cleaning photo flow rather than as a separate screen/task. Show cleaning photos + review interface on same screen.
evidence.insight: The MetroCard Vending Machine lesson: embedding related actions in the same visual context (same screen) is faster and less intimidating than mode switching. Apply this to cleaning photo â†’ review transition.

evidence.quote: Having quickly graspable bits of information made the transaction much faster than trying to save screens.
evidence.insight: Same principle from the MetroCard story. Don't force the user to navigate to a new screen for the review. Show it in context, right after the cleaning photo. Visual continuity = cognitive continuity.

evidence.quote: Fast response, gentle settle. User actions feel instant (< 100ms acknowledgment) but transitions are smooth (300-500ms).
evidence.insight: The slide-up animation should feel smooth (300ms) but not slow. The user should feel the review card is RESPONDING to their photo submission, not appearing randomly.

evidence.quote: --avatar-sm: 36px for inline avatars, lists
evidence.insight: Use a similar small image size (60px) for the cleaning photo thumbnail in the review card. It's recognizable but doesn't dominate the card. Provides visual anchor to the previous context.

new_tokens_needed: --thumbnail-review-photo: 60px (size for contextual photo in review card)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for 'How was your stay?' heading text. Card shadow should be subtle (0.08 opacity) to maintain soft visual weight.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Thumbnail is ANCHOR element (top-left, small) â†’ Heading is CONTEXT setter (next to thumbnail) â†’ Star rating is PRIMARY action (centered, below heading). The thumbnail doesn't compete visually, it orients.
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'Warm, not cold.' The cleaning photo thumbnail adds human warmthâ€”it's a visual reminder of the real space, not an abstract form. Also aligns with 'The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' The thumbnail is functional (provides context), not decorative.

elements.title: Pricing Clarity Typographic Hierarchy (Guest Journey Consistency)
elements.problem: Tapper's call (lines 22-45) reveals catastrophic pricing confusion: per-bedroom vs full-unit pricing, fee ambiguity, manual calculation burden. He initially thought rent was $2,092/month but discovered it was per bedroom, doubling expected cost. This confusion is a VISUAL HIERARCHY failure. When all pricing numbers look the same size and weight, guests can't distinguish total cost from per-night rate from per-bedroom rate. Layer 2 (communicates-004) defines the INFORMATION architecture. Layer 3 must define the VISUAL hierarchy to make that information scannable.
elements.solution: Use dramatic typographic scale to create scannable pricing hierarchy: (1) **DOMINANT**: Total lease cost in --text-4xl: 36px, --font-weight-bold: 700, --primary-purple: #31135D. This is 2.5x larger than any other pricing number. (2) **SECONDARY**: Per-month breakdown in --text-lg: 18px, --font-weight-medium: 500, --text-gray: #6b7280. (3) **TERTIARY**: Calculation breakdown (per-night Ã— nights Ã— weeks) in --text-sm: 12px, --font-weight-normal: 400, --text-light-gray: #9ca3af. (4) **QUATERNARY**: Per-bedroom clarification in --text-sm: 12px, --signal-warn: #c17a28 (warm orange) background badge, --text-dark text. Use the style guide's monospace font (--font-mono: IBM Plex Mono) for all pricing numbers to signal precision and trustworthiness. Position total cost top-left (Western reading pattern) with 24px bottom margin to separate from breakdown.

evidence.quote: it says four week rent, 2090 $2, if you select full time. Um, what does that include? Does that include the fees for booking? ... so 74, 73 per night, that is per, and it is two bedroom. I just don't want to, uh, to mislead you, this is per bedroom.
evidence.insight: Tapper couldn't distinguish what number meant what. All pricing looked the same visually. This caused a 2x cost miscalculation and nearly caused dropout. VISUAL HIERARCHY is the solutionâ€”make the most important number (total cost) dramatically larger and more prominent.

evidence.quote: DOMINANT: Total lease cost in guest's terms ('$6,000 total' or '$2,000/month Ã— 3 months'). This number should be 2-3x larger font than any other pricing info.
evidence.insight: Information architecture defines the hierarchy. Visual design IMPLEMENTS the hierarchy through font size, weight, and color. 2-3x larger font size creates instant visual dominanceâ€”the eye can't miss it.

evidence.quote: Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges). IBM Plex Mono â€” signals precision and reliability.
evidence.insight: Use the monospace font for ALL pricing numbers to create visual consistency and signal trustworthiness. Monospace = data = precision = trust.

evidence.quote: --text-4xl: 36px (hero headings), --text-lg: 18px (large body text), --text-sm: 12px (small text, captions)
evidence.insight: The style guide provides a 3:1 scale ratio (36px â†’ 18px â†’ 12px) that creates clear visual hierarchy. Use this scale for pricing to make the hierarchy unmistakable.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text. Total cost at 36px and bold = 3:1 minimum against background. Warning badge must meet 4.5:1 for 12px text.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Eye sees: (1) Total cost (largest, purple, top-left), (2) Per-month breakdown (medium, gray, below), (3) Calculation details (small, light gray, expandable), (4) Warning badge if applicable (orange background, high contrast). Western reading pattern (top-left) + size dominance = instant comprehension.
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' The dramatic size difference isn't flashyâ€”it's functional clarity. Also aligns with 'Trustworthy, not corporate. Real data.' Using monospace font for numbers signals data precision and builds trust.

elements.title: Pre-Populated Review Visual Differentiation (Don't Start from Zero)
elements.problem: Layer 2 (communicates-003) establishes pre-population of review ratings from previous stays. But visually, how do guests distinguish pre-filled data from blank fields? If pre-filled stars look identical to manually selected stars, guests might not realize they can just confirm and submit. If there's no visual cue that 'this is from last time,' the cognitive benefit of pre-population is lost. Guests need to SEE at a glance: 'Oh, this is already filled in from my previous review.'
elements.solution: Use subtle visual differentiation for pre-populated vs manually selected states: (1) **Pre-populated stars**: Fill with --primary-purple at 60% opacity and add a small label above rating: 'Same as last time' in --text-xs: 11px, --text-light-gray color, italic style. (2) **Manually selected stars**: Fill with --primary-purple at 100% opacity, no label. (3) **'Confirm âœ“' button**: For reviews 5+, show a large, pill-shaped button (--rounded-pill: 20px, --secondary-purple background, 100% card width) with text 'Same as last time âœ“' in --text-md: 16px, --font-weight-semibold: 600. Tapping this button submits the pre-populated review. The button's size and color (bright purple) makes it the primary action. If the guest taps a star to change the rating, the button fades out (200ms opacity transition) and a standard 'Submit' button appears, signaling the shift from 'confirm' to 'create new.'

evidence.quote: For reviews 5+: Lead with 'Same as last time âœ“' button above the rating interface. If guest ignores button and interacts with rating/comment fields, button fades to secondary position.
evidence.insight: The information architecture defines the interaction pattern. Visual design must make the 'Same as last time' option VISUALLY DOMINANT through size, color, and position. A large, purple, full-width button achieves this.

evidence.quote: Don't Start from Zero: Rules should be designed to pre-populate with known data.
evidence.insight: Pre-population is a RULE. But the FEEDBACK (visual design) must communicate that the rule is active. Guests need to SEE that the system remembers their previous rating. Opacity differentiation and a label ('Same as last time') provide that feedback.

evidence.quote: Pre-population transforms the review from an active writing task to a passive confirmation task. This cognitive shiftâ€”from generation to recognitionâ€”reduces effort by ~80%.
evidence.insight: The VISUAL design must support the cognitive shift. A passive confirmation task should LOOK different from an active creation task. The large 'Same as last time âœ“' button signals 'you can just tap this and be done'â€”a passive action. Standard star rating signals 'you need to think and choose'â€”an active action.

evidence.quote: --secondary-purple: rgb(109, 49, 194) for interactive buttons, CTAs. --rounded-pill: 20px for pill-shaped buttons.
evidence.insight: Use the brand's CTA styling (secondary purple, pill shape) for the 'Same as last time' button to make it unmistakably interactive and primary. Full-width increases tap target and visual prominence.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for confirm button (white text on secondary purple = 7:1+, excellent). Pre-populated stars at 60% opacity should still be recognizable as purple (3:1 minimum contrast against background).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: For reviews 5+: Confirm button is PRIMARY (large, bright purple, full-width, top of card). Pre-populated stars are SECONDARY (visible but lower opacity). For reviews 1-4: Stars are PRIMARY (100% opacity, no confirm button). The hierarchy shifts based on loop countâ€”visual design adapts to user's position in the long loop.
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'Relentless Personalization: The UI should adapt to who you are and where you are in your journey.' The confirm button only appears for reviews 5+, personalizing the UI based on usage history. Also aligns with 'One signature animation per componentâ€”restraint over spectacle.' The button fade-out (200ms) is the only animationâ€”subtle, not showy.

elements.title: Review Prompt Contextual Metadata Visual Layout
elements.problem: Layer 2 (communicates-002) establishes that review prompts must show stay metadata (property name, dates, nights) to refresh memory and provide context. But HOW should this metadata be laid out visually? If it's buried in small text at the bottom, guests might miss it. If it's too prominent, it competes with the primary action (star rating). The visual layout must balance 'context-setting' (important) with 'not visually dominant' (secondary to rating action).
elements.solution: Create a compact metadata header at the top of the review card, above the star rating: (1) **Property name**: --text-md: 16px, --font-weight-semibold: 600, --text-dark: #1a1a1a. (2) **Date range + nights**: --text-sm: 12px, --font-weight-normal: 400, --text-gray: #6b7280, on a single line below property name (e.g., 'Nov 3-7 â€¢ 4 nights'). Use a bullet separator (â€¢) between date and nights for visual rhythm. (3) **Property thumbnail**: If using the cleaning photo thumbnail (looks-004), position it to the left of the text at 60px x 60px with --spacing-md: 12px right margin. This creates a horizontal layout: [Thumbnail] [Property name + Date/nights]. Total header height: ~80px. Add --spacing-lg: 16px bottom margin to separate from star rating. Use --border-subtle bottom border (1px) to create visual separation between context and action zones.

evidence.quote: Show metadata immediately in the notification preview and repeat full metadata at the top of the review form. Don't bury context below the foldâ€”it must be visible before any rating interface appears.
evidence.insight: Information architecture defines WHAT to show and WHERE (top of form). Visual design defines HOW to lay it out (horizontal vs vertical, size, spacing) to make it scannable without dominating.

evidence.quote: Bring the Data Forward: The trigger itself can reflect the data contained inside the microinteraction. Ask yourself, what can I show about the internal state before the user even engages?
evidence.insight: The metadata header BRINGS THE DATA FORWARDâ€”it shows stay details before the guest even starts rating. This is visual feedback that answers 'which stay am I reviewing?' before the question is consciously asked.

evidence.quote: And that's why I am asking because, uh, at this point of time, uh, when I take your $2,500 and divided by four weeks and divided by five nights, that is 1 25 per night. I'm just giving you the calculations I'm doing in my mind very quickly.
evidence.insight: Tapper manually reconstructed context (dates, nights, cost) that the system should have shown. The same applies to reviewsâ€”guests shouldn't have to mentally reconstruct 'which stay was this?' The metadata header provides instant context.

evidence.quote: --border-subtle: #F0F1F3 for barely visible section dividers, --spacing-lg: 16px for section padding
evidence.insight: Use a subtle bottom border (--border-subtle, 1px) to create visual separation between the metadata header and the rating section. 16px bottom margin provides breathing room.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for property name (16px, semibold = 4.5:1 minimum). Date/nights text at 12px requires 4.5:1 minimum contrast.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Metadata header is CONTEXT zone (top 25% of card). Star rating is ACTION zone (middle 50% of card). Comment/issue are OPTIONAL zones (bottom 25%). Eye reads top-to-bottom: context â†’ action â†’ optional details. The border creates a visual 'fold' separating context from action.
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' The metadata header feels polished and informative, providing context without overwhelming. Also aligns with 'The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' The layout is functional, not decorativeâ€”every element has a purpose.

elements.title: Acceptance Phase Review Norm Visual Framing
elements.problem: Layer 2 (communicates-007) and Layer 1 (works-005) establish that the acceptance phase (lease signing) should explicitly set expectations for stay-by-stay reviews. But how should this information be VISUALLY presented in the lease confirmation email or contract? If it's buried in dense legal text, guests won't read it. If it's too prominent, it might create anxiety ('Wait, I have to review 12 times?!'). The visual design must balance 'clear and noticeable' with 'friendly and reassuring.'
elements.solution: Create a visually distinct 'How Reviews Work' callout box in the lease confirmation email: (1) **Container**: Light purple background (--protocol-surface: #F7F2FA from style guide), --rounded-xl: 12px border radius, --spacing-2xl: 24px internal padding, --shadow-sm: subtle shadow for lift. (2) **Icon**: Small calendar icon (--icon-md: 24px) in --primary-purple at top-left. (3) **Heading**: 'How Reviews Work' in --text-lg: 18px, --font-weight-semibold: 600, --primary-purple. (4) **Body text**: 2-3 sentences in --text-base: 14px, --font-weight-normal: 400, --text-dark, --line-height-relaxed: 1.6 for readability. (5) **Key stats**: Highlight '15 seconds' and 'after each stay' in --font-weight-semibold and --secondary-purple color for emphasis. (6) **Visual preview**: Include a small mockup image (200px wide) of the review card interface below the text to make it concrete. Total callout box: ~300px wide in email, centered. This creates a 'signature moment' in the onboarding flowâ€”a visually distinct, friendly explanation that sets expectations without feeling like fine print.

evidence.quote: HIERARCHY within section: (1) HEADLINE: 'After each stay, we'll ask for quick feedback' (what to expect), (2) BODY: 15-second time estimate, mutual expectation, benefit to guest, (3) VISUAL: Screenshot/preview of review interface.
evidence.insight: Information architecture defines the content hierarchy. Visual design implements it through typography scale, color emphasis, and layout. The callout box creates visual separation from the rest of the email, making the section 'pop' without being aggressive.

evidence.source: Microinteractions extract, lines 234-241 (Loops chapter, Acceptance phase)
evidence.quote: Acceptance is the moment to introduce the 'long loop' of stay-by-stay reviews. Set the expectation NOW that reviews happen after each stay, not just at lease end. Make it feel like a recurring ritual, not a one-time request.
evidence.insight: Visual framing creates the 'ritual' feeling. A callout box with a calendar icon signals 'this is a recurring pattern.' The light purple background (brand color) signals 'this is important and part of the Split Lease experience,' not an afterthought.

evidence.quote: --protocol-surface: #F7F2FA for surface backgrounds (light purple tint)
evidence.insight: Use the protocol surface color to create a visually distinct but brand-aligned callout box. It's purple (brand) but light (friendly, not heavy).

evidence.quote: Warm, not cold. Soft backgrounds, not stark white. Trustworthy, not corporate.
evidence.insight: The callout box background (light purple, not white or gray) creates warmth. The rounded corners (12px) and soft shadow create approachability. The visual preview image makes it concrete and trustworthy ('here's exactly what you'll see').

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all text. Heading at 18px and semibold = 4.5:1 minimum against light purple background. Body text at 14px = 4.5:1 minimum. Emphasized text (secondary purple) must also meet 4.5:1 against light purple background.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: In the email: (1) Lease confirmation details (largest, top), (2) 'How Reviews Work' callout box (medium, visually distinct via background color and border radius), (3) Move-in instructions (below). The callout box is PROMINENT but not DOMINANTâ€”it's noticeable but doesn't overshadow the primary lease confirmation info.
elements.brand_alignment: Connects to taste model's 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' The callout box feels polished (soft shadow, rounded corners, branded color) but friendly (light background, relaxed line height, visual preview). Also aligns with 'Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' The box is simple and clear, not overly designed.
